page.title: 07BLACKPOOL BRIDGE
page.content: Blackpool Bridge is the part of the forest where 'the forest's most scenic road' joins the B4431. The bridge once carried the railway line from the forest's mining areas to the main line from Gloucester to S. Wales. Near the bridge there is an exposed section of Roman road some 20 metres long and 2.5 metres wide. Some people believe the road existed in pre-Roman times and that they adopted it and re-paved it. This exposed section reveals the road to be well edged; the original line of the road through Blackpool Brook is clearly visible as is the later easterly diversion over a narrow bridge which now carries this scenic road. The nearby notice reads,"ROMAN ROAD - LYNDEY TO MITCHELDEAN - KNOWN LENGTH 10\ MILES - PROBABLY 1ST OR 2ND CENTURY A.D."
